snippet: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to impose stringent new screening procedures on people from Syria and Iraq seeking resettlement in the United States.
abstract: House votes 289-137 to greatly tighten screening procedures on refugees from Syria and Iraq, jeopardizing Pres Obama's Middle East policy; more than two dozen governors, including a Democrat, support blocking Syrian refugees from entering their states, and recent Bloomberg poll shows more  than 50 percent of Americans agree with strategy; bill's fate in Senate is uncertain but Obama administration promises veto if it passes both chambers.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
byline.contributor: Jennifer Steinhauer reported from Washington, and Michael D. Shear from Manila.

lead_paragraph: Lawmakers voted overwhelmingly to impose stringent new screening procedures on people from Syria and Iraq seeking resettlement in the United States.

headline.main: House Approves Tougher Refugee Screening, Defying Veto Threat
headline.print_headline: Bill to Restrict Syrians in U.S. Passes in House

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
